title: RS22055
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) authorizes federal funding for children with disabilities, requiring the provision of a free appropriate public education (FAPE) and detailed due process provisions. Attorneys' fees provisions were added in 1986 and amended in 1997 and 2004. The 2004 IDEA reauthorization included changes to attorneys' fees provisions, allowing fees for the state or local educational agency against parents or their attorneys in certain situations. Complaint and appeals procedures remained mostly unchanged, with the addition of LEAs being able to file complaints. Under the 2004 IDEA reauthorization, attorneys' fees provisions were updated to allow for fees to be awarded in certain situations. Complaint and appeals procedures remained mostly the same, with the addition of LEAs being able to file complaints. Parents or LEAs can file complaints regarding various aspects of a child's education, leading to an impartial due process hearing and the right to appeal. Attorneys' fees may be awarded to the prevailing party, and fees can also be awarded against a parent's attorney in specific circumstances. Under the 2004 IDEA reauthorization, attorneys' fees provisions were updated to allow for fees to be awarded in certain situations. P.L. 108-446 also allows for attorneys' fees against attorneys of parents of children with disabilities or parents to prevailing SEAs or LEAs in cases of frivolous or unreasonable litigation. Senators Grassley and Gregg emphasized the need for the attorneys' fee amendment to prevent abuses of due process rights and ensure taxpayer dollars go towards educating children. Senator Gregg highlighted the importance of the attorneys' fee amendment, citing the high standard for prevailing defendants to recover fees in cases of frivolous or unreasonable litigation. The provision also allows for fee recovery if lawsuits are brought for an improper purpose, drawing from Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The attorneys' fee provision allows prevailing defendants to recover fees if lawsuits are brought for an improper purpose. Senator Gregg noted that courts must apply an objective standard of reasonableness to the facts of the case. Attorneys' fees are based on prevailing community rates with specific prohibitions and reductions in fee amounts. Fees may not be awarded for services performed after a written settlement offer under certain circumstances. Additionally, attorneys' fees are not awarded for IEP team meetings unless convened as a result of an. The court finds that the relief obtained by the parents is not more favorable than the settlement offer. Attorneys' fees are not awarded for IEP team meetings unless convened due to administrative or judicial action, or for a mediation. The 2004 reauthorization added a "resolution session" requirement before a due process hearing, where attorneys' fees are not allowable. P.L. 108-446 allows attorneys' fees for a prevailing parent who was justified in rejecting a settlement offer, but fees may be reduced if the resolution is unreasonably prolonged. Attorneys' fees may be reduced in certain circumstances including where the court finds that the parent or the parent's attorney unreasonably protracted the final resolution of the controversy; the amount of attorneys' fees unreasonably exceeds the hourly rate prevailing in the community for similar services by attorneys of reasonably comparable skill, reputation and experience; where the time spent and legal services furnished were excessive considering the nature of the action or proceedings; or the attorney representing the parent did not provide the school district with the appropriate information in the due process complaint. This information includes the name of the child, the child's address and school, or available contact information in the case of a homeless child, a description of the problem, including facts relating to the issue, and a proposed resolution to the problem. There shall be no reduction if the court finds that the SEA or LEA unreasonably protracted the final resolution of the action or proceeding or there was a violation of the section. The final regulations for P.L. 108-446 were issued on August 14, 2006, with the Department of Education declining to provide further guidance on the interpretation of statutory language regarding attorneys' fees. They noted that lay advocates are not entitled to compensation as attorneys, and did not address whether fees could be awarded to non-attorney advocates. The Department of Education stated that lay advocates are not entitled to compensation as attorneys, citing the Supreme Court's decision in Arlington Central School District Board of Education v. Murphy. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA did not include explicit language authorizing recovery of experts' fees by prevailing parents. The Department of Education declined to add a regulatory provision on the subject.
